div.head: A GARTER FOR LORD CROMER
div.p: What is to be Lord Cromer’s reward ? On every side the desire is expressed, says the Liberal organ, "The Tribune," that the services of the great Pro-consul shall be recognized by the conferment of some signal honour to mark the nation's gratitude upon the completion of the memorable epoch in the history of the Empire.

What form the reward shall take is already, the subjet of keep discussion, but such a wealth of honours has been heaped upon Lord Cromer during his diplomatic career that the choice of elevation has become somewhat circumscribed He is a member of tho Privy Council. He has received the Grand Cross Of the Oders of the Bath and the St. Michael and St. George. He is a Knight Commander of the Star of Indian, a Companion of the Order of the Indian Empire, and one of the fifteen British members of the Order of Merit. Finally, during his administration he has been successively created baron (1892), viscount (1898). and earl (1901).

Among the many suggestions which are being thrown out, the moat general appear to be that Lord Cromer shall be given a further step in the peerage or receive a money grant. As far as can be ascertained there is no precedent whatever for the grant of a sum ol money to a retiring diplomat. It has often been done in the case of a military commander fresh from a successful campaign, and the cases of Lord Kitchener and Lord Roberts are still fresh in the public mind.

But the great civilian is not similarly favoured, and the case of Lord Dufferin is decisive as to the practice on such occasions. Lord Dufferin had rendered unexampled services to this country during his occupancy of the offices of Viceroy of India, Governor-General of Canada, and Ambassador at St Petersburg, Constantinople, Rome, and Paris, but though notoriously a poor man, he received no financial recognition beyond the customary pension on his retirement from the Diplomatic Service in 1896 Not only slid he not receive a giant on leaving the Paris Embassy, but he was not specially honoured in any way.

Precedent also is against Lord Cromer in the circumstances receiving a marquisate. The Earl of Hopetoun was certainly created Marquess of Linlithgow on resigning tha Governor-Generalship of Australia in 1902, but this was merely an enhanced dignity for an old peerage. The same applies to the marquisate conferred upon Lord Ripor upon the settlement of the Alabama claims in 1871, and in a less degree to the title bestowed upon Lord Dufferiu in 1888 at the close of his Viceroyalty. In neither case was the marquisate conferred at the close of a career, and neither recipient began public life as a commoner, as Lord Cromer did. It is further pointed out that even a Prime Minister of this country sitting in the Commons has no claim upon a higher title than that of EarL Walpole, the elder Pitt, and Disraeli received earldoms, and it is an open secret that Mr. Gladstone refused one.

There is, however, an honour far transcending that of a step in the peerage which may fittingly and with sufficient precedent be conferred upon Lord Cromer In well-informed quarters the belief is entertained that be will be offered the Garter. By tradition the Garter is the gift of the King, and its conferment upon Lord Cromer would have an international significance, seeing that it is the order associated with sovereignty. The precedent is a very striking one— that of Lord Stratford de Redcliffe, “the Great Elchi,” who received the Garter in 1869 in recognition of his services as Ambassador at Constantinople. Stratford Canning’s Garter was especially noteworthy because it was one of the extremely rare instances of that favour being bestowed upon a peer below the rank of an Earl.

At the present moment the Order of the Garter has its full complement of twenty-four knights, the most recent vacancy having been filled by Earl Carrington, Lord Stratford had to wait for a vacancy before receiving the Garter, but there is a precedent for temporarily raising the number of knights in exceptional circumstances. When Disraeli and Lord Salisbury returned from Berlin in 1878, after negotiating the famous treaty, both statesmen were given the Garter, although there was only one vacancy.
If Lord Cromer becomes a Knight of the Garter on his return from Egypt a deserved honour will have been conferred without creating the possibility of a dangerous precedent.

Donkey Polo in Sennar

There is a delightful touch of humour contained in that portion of Lord Cromer's Report which deals with the Sudan. In summarising Major Wilson’s report on the province of Sennar, Lord Cromer remarks that the “following observation is characteristic of British administration. Major Wilson writes : ‘Advantage was taken of the pressence of numerous head sheikhs at the cotton show to initiate them into the game of polo on donkeys. Matches were played between teams of sheikhs, who took to the game in an extraordinary manner. ” The “Spectator" in commenting on this passage remarks : “It seems to us that Major Wilson by his bold experiment with the Sennar sheikhs may have unconsciously produced world-wide results. Polo on donkeys would be an admirable new sport for elderly men of action for whom real polo has become too dangerous. We also recommend donkey polo to enterprising hostesses in country houses anxious to find amusement for their guests. Most mining villages, as well as most seaside resorts, ought easily to be able to produce eight donkeys to make a beginning, while country houses in Kent and Essex would have the whole of the coster donkeys of the East End to draw upon. We wonder whether the donkeys soon get keen on the game like ponies, and learn to follow the ball. Also, do their ears get in the way ?”

div.head: TROUBLES IN CAIRO.
div.p: SERIOUS DISTURBANCES.
MILITARY DEMONSTRATION

A serious state of affairs prevails in Cairo and there is a very uneasy feeling prevalent that troubles of a grave nature may break out. So seriously indeed is the situation regarded by the officials that Mr Machell, Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior, who had left on a journey to Mariout, has had to be recalled to Cairo. The strike of the cabmen, as we announced on Friday, is over and on Saturday the cabs were plying as usual. But as soon as this strike had been settled the carters began to rise up and a grave series of outrages took place on Saturday, which has alarmed the inhabitants of the Capital, for the movement is not considered to be solely provoked by economical reasons. At 11 am. a large mob, consisting of many hundreds of natives, assembled suddenly at the khalig near Darb el Gamamy and at once began to savagely attack the trams. The mob broke the windows, maltreated the employes of the Tramway company and the passengers: all traffic was stopped and the street blocked. At the same time another huge mob gathered together in the Gouvernoat square Mansfield Pasha harangued them in Arabic and the mounted police cleared the square. Twenty employes of the Cairo Tramway Company have been injured and forty-three tram cars have been damaged. It is considered that these outrages have been inspired by some well-known persons who want to encourage disorder for their own purposes.

The serious outrages in the trams have no perceptible connection with either the strike ol the cabmen or the carters. There were other outbursts of the mob and at Abou el Ala bridge a crowd assembled. The manifests, who had a threatening attitude, were prevented from doing any harm and the police made some arrests. All traffic on the tram lines at Boulac, Old Cairo, and the Khalig was suspended at 6 p.m. and on the other lines at between 9 and 10 p.m. Egyptian troops were stationed at the poliee posts.
POPULAR ALARM.

The Cairo newspapers express the alarm felt generally at these disorders. “Les Pyramides" remarks “what is particularly disquieting in this one is that the outcry is not made against the employers, as is usually the case in strike troubles, but against the Government and its agents. Some people are asking themselves whether these demands, whose object is to alarm public opinion and which, moreover, are not due to trade interests, do not conceal political issues are fomented by some people whose interest it is to disturb the water in order to fish the better.”

The “Journal du Caire” in its issue of Saturday also expresses the popular alarm at these sudden and simultaneous outbreaks ot disorder after the cessation of the cab Strike. It remarks : ‘We had good reason to declare in ourlast issue that there were evilly disposed persons who wished to fish in troubled water. This cannot any longer admit of the slightest doubt in view of the fresh outbreak of disorder this morning. The cabs are plying again and yet the trams are attacked ! Why is this ? What can he the motive for it! Who are the people who are directing it. We hold that we have the right to put these questions and it is the duty of the police to answer. This stupid but suggestive agitation has continued too long. These recent events clearly show that at the present time there is a large number of people in Cairo without any occupation, whose pleasure it is to utilise their leisure in the refined amusement of maltreating the passengers and the staff of the tramways. In such a case the poliee in every country in the world sweeps them away and clears the town of this disagreeable class. When are we to have a clearance at Cairo ?’

It is to be noted as a coincidence of some significance that both these newspapers, from which we have quoted, and which appear at the same time,make use of the same expression “pecher en eau trouble.”
LATEST NEWS.

Our Cairo correspondent telephoning to-day at 1 p.m. states that there has been no renewal of the disorders to-day. Last night the whole force of the Cairo City Police were on duty and in readiness for any emergency. The Ministry of the Interior had taken special measures to ensure the safety of the Cairo Gouvernorat from attack and it was guarded by soldiers. Throughout yesterday there was a vague presentiment of coming troubles and a renewal of the disturbances but no incidents of a serious character are reported.
The carters of Cairo, who are among the roughest elements of the populace, remain quiet.
The troops of the Anny of Occupation were called out last night and paraded round the Boulac quarter, where the troubles appeared to be the gravest.
The demonstration has had, it is hoped, a good effect. If, however, the disorders continue the most severe measures will be token to ensure quiet.

Extraordinarily disquieting rumours were afloat at Alexandria this morning as to the state of affairs in the Capital and it was confidently announced that the troops of the Army of Occupation had had to be called out. The news exerted a very bad effect in the Bourse and considerable nervousness was the result.

div.head: LORD CROMERS RESIGNATION
div.p: MEETING AT ALEXANDRIA.

The special committee of the Alexandria Municipal Commission couvened a general meeting at the Municipal Palace at 11 o’clock yesterday morning in order to discuss the question of a memorial to Lord Cromer. The attendance was very representative, with the noticeable exception that outside the representatives of the Press there was not a single Moslem present. The discussion was long and desultory and the meeting did not break up until 1.30 p m. Some confusion has been caused owing to the fact that after the special committee of the Municipality had sent a letter to Lord Cromer and had received a reply from his lordship in favour of a tuberculous institution, a letter was received from the President of the Council of Ministers asking Alexandria to join with Cairo. The Cairo committee had nominated some Alexandria to serve on a general committee but had neglected to ask the Alexandria Municipality to select some of its members for this purpose. Mr. Salvago strongly protested in the name of the Municipality at this treatment. The Municipality was the most important representative institution in Egypt and was representative of Alexandria, and it was a grave want of taste not to ask it officially to select some of its members to serve on the committee and to ignore the fact that the Municipality had taken the initiative in the matter.

It was decided that Schiess Pasha, Mr. Salvago and Pados Bey should go to Cairo in order to discuss the question with the committee there and put forward Alexandria’s views. It was also agreed that Alexandria should take part in the manifestation at the Khedivial Oprea House and that the city should be represented on that occasion by delegates of the Municipality and the corporations. There was a strong feeling that the memorial should be in Alexandria, but at the same time the meeting was in favour of working in accord with Cairo and the rest of Egypt. It was decided that a tubercolous institution was the most useful form which a memorial should take and that if such an instution should come into being, it was to be international and undenominational and that arrangements as to the food supply should be such as not in any way to impinge on Jewish or Moslem scruples in the same way as the Rudolph Home.
CAIRO COMMITTER

The committee provisionally formed to organise a public demonstration iu honour of Lord Cromer has decided that the ceremony shall take place on May 4th at 6 o'clock in the Opera House. A sub committee will prepare and issue invitations to as many as the theatre will hold. There will be two speeches in the name of the committee and Lord Cromer will reply. The committee has approved in principle the opening of a general subscription to be devoted to such a purpose as shall be eventually determined ; it has, moreover, recommended that the Municipality of Alexandria be invited with a view to the dignity of the occasion to cooperate with the Cairo committee by delegating such of their members as they may think best. Similar invitations will be issued to the other towns of Egypt, in order to allow all who are desirous of joining in the demonstration the opportunity to associate themselves with the measure finally adopted by the committee.

(a) A modification of the contract, dated the 27th of Septemeber, 1906, and made between the Ritz Hotels and Development Co Lts. of the one part and Henry William Stickland on behalf of the company of the other part, as adopted by the agreement, dated the 12th day of December 1906, whereby the Company will become at liberty to extend or enlarge the hotel in course of erection by it, and to aquire or be interested in any new property without obtaining the consent of the development company, and without having to pay to the development company in respect of such consent a commision upon the shares or debentures to be paid in the future by the company for the purpose of such extension, enlargement or acquistion.

Clause 7 of such contract, so far as it relates to future prospectuses, and clauses Nos. 11, 12 and 13 therefore, and clause 9, expect so far as relates to the appointement of a Manager of the said Hotel, will be canceled

(b) a modification of the contract dated 27th September, 1906, and made between the development company of the 1st part, Charles Bacos of the 2nd part and the Nile Land and Agricultural Co. of the 3rd part, whereby Charles Bacos and the land company obtain liberty to be interested in other hotels in Egypt, and to use the namre of Ritz without consent of the development Co,. but not without the consent of the Ritz Hotels (Egypt) Limited and without being liable to pay a commission to the development as by the modified contract provided. The consideration for the said modifications is the payment by the company to the development company of the sume of twenty thousand pounds sterling.

By the latter of these contracts, which is part of the same arrangement, the company agrees to indemnify the development company against all claims by Mr. Ceaser Ritz under an agreement dated 20th November 1906, referred to in a prospectues of the Company and also in respect of an agreement made by the company with Barson Hand Pfyffer, dated the 6th December, 1906, under which these gentlemen would have become entitled to share in the future commission, and the benefits of such agreements are transferred to the company, Mr. Ritz and Baron Hans Pfyffer releasing all claim to the £20,000 above referred to.
On the motion Mr. Mosseri, seconded by Matire Carton de Wiart, it was resolved unanimously that tese contratcs be approved. Neither Baron Pfyffer, Mr. Matesdorf nor Mr. Bacos voted.
Mr. Matesdorf then addressed the meeting on behalf of the chairman as follows. :-

"As you are aware, the issue has been a great success , and the building of the hotel has been commenced and is going ahead with all speed compatible with good contraction Unfortunately contract prices for building material and operations had gone up considerably. We shall call you to an extrordinary meeting soon which will lutve several questions to consider.

“It is desirable to transferthe management to Egypt instead of having it in London, and the London board cannot under these circumstances continue the responsibility of control. This will necessitate a number of changes in the articles of association, which will to submitted for your approval. Then we are going to considerably enlarge the sphere to operations and do other hotel and property buisness at Cairo and Alexandria, and probably elsewhere. Again, we propose to abolish entirely the founders’ shares and we will submit to you an arrangement which we consider equitable. All these proposals will require an increase of capital. We trust, subject to other arrangements, to obtain a sufficient guarantee of capital by the placing of shares at a suitable price. I hope that these projects will contribute to the success of our enterprise.’’
Mr. Matesdorf on behalf of the chairman then thanked the shareholders for their attendance at the meeting. The proceedings were then terminated with a hearty vote of thanks to the chairman.
